credentialTypes.label: Associate Certificate
credentialTypes.shortDescription: Short, focused credentials made up of a small group of courses that target a specific area of practice.

credentialTypes.label: Certificate
credentialTypes.shortDescription: A broader business credential that covers multiple functional areas and can ladder into a diploma.
credentialTypes.typicalLength: About 10 courses or equivalent combinations of associate certificates.

regions.label: Northern British Columbia
regions.description: Includes the Cariboo, Nechako, Prince George, and surrounding communities where CNC learners live and work.

labourMarketNotes.dataSource: Program descriptions draw on BC and regional labour market information for projected openings, job titles, and typical wages where available.
labourMarketNotes.wageNote: All wage ranges mentioned are approximate and can vary based on employer, collective agreements, sector, experience, and location.
labourMarketNotes.outlookNote: Opportunity bands are relative indicators based on expected openings, replacement needs, and demand for related occupations. They do not guarantee employment but highlight patterns in the labour market.

plarGlobal.title: Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition (PLAR)
plarGlobal.intro: Many CNC business credentials can recognize prior learning gained through work, community involvement, and non credit training. PLAR can shorten the time it takes to complete a credential by granting credit where learning outcomes have already been met.
commonEvidence: Employer letters that describe duties and responsibilities related to program outcomes.
Work samples such as reports, spreadsheets, project plans, schedules, or policy documents that demonstrate applied skills.
Records of non credit training, workshops, sector certifications, or in house courses that align with program content.
Interviews, challenge exams, or practical assessments that confirm knowledge and skills.
plarGlobal.disclaimer: Final decisions about PLAR are made by CNC using current policies, program learning outcomes, and the evidence provided by each applicant. PLAR availability and processes may change over time.
